summary:
Inktober Day 5: Chicken
CRinktober Day 5: Life
Pike's whole deal is keeping people alive, isn't it? But also living life to its...
body:
Inktober Day 5: Chicken

CRinktober Day 5: Life

Pike’s whole deal is keeping people alive, isn’t it? But also living life to its fullest. Such as in situations where punching chickens with your new magically enhanced strength is the most important objective.

summary: A lot of this episode is amazing (one of the most fun so far!) but an absolute standout moment for me has to be: “Oh, was I...
body:
A lot of this episode is amazing (one of the most fun so far!) but an absolute standout moment for me has to be:

“Oh, was I eating cheese?!” And then he just goes with it.

That was such peak DnD, I died.

reblog.comment:
A lot of this episode is amazing (one of the most fun so far!) but an absolute standout moment for me has to be:

“Oh, was I eating cheese?!” And then he just goes with it.

That was such peak DnD, I died.

trail.content_raw:
A lot of this episode is amazing (one of the most fun so far!) but an absolute standout moment for me has to be:

“Oh, was I eating cheese?!” And then he just goes with it.

That was such peak DnD, I died.
trail.content:
A lot of this episode is amazing (one of the most fun so far!) but an absolute standout moment for me has to be:

“Oh, was I eating cheese?!” And then he just goes with it.

That was such peak DnD, I died.

blog.name: critrole-imagines
blog.title: this is what we've built with our tiny moments
blog.description: REQUESTS: OPEN! welcome to critrole imagines! i fulfill critical role based writing requests! feel free to send me stuff!

summary: can you do sunlight with Keyleth and maybe Tary or Pike? or maybe even the sun tree!
question: can you do sunlight with Keyleth and maybe Tary or Pike? or maybe even the sun tree!
answer:
Wilhand always said that Pike was a child of the sun.

Always smiling, always loud and cheerful and full of light that, even at a young age, she shared with everyone.

Maybe that’s what’s helping her keep her faith. Sarenrae is the godess of second chances, and every sunrise marks another chance, doesn’t it? A fresh start.

Today the sun stands high in the cloudless sky above Whitestone, and it’s warm enough that Pike has actually left her cloak in the castle. Percy assured her that this is about as warm as it gets up here, so she’s making the best of it.

It’s been only two weeks since they fought the Briarwoods. Since Percy took back his home and found his long lost sister.

The town is recovering slowly. It’s like it’s people are still in disbelief that they’re actually free. But Whitestone is so much better now. It’s not grey and dark anymore. It’s drenched in sunlight. Pelor’s blessing is back.

Pike finds Keyleth in the center of town, sitting underneath the Sun Tree with a book in her hand. She has one hand resting on the bark of the crippled tree and it absentmindedly petting it like an animal as she reads.

“How… is he?” Pike asks, a little awkward because she still doesn’t quite understand the connection Keyleth has to nature.

Keyleth looks up at her and smiles. “Doing much better. He says he’s missed the sun.”

Pike nods. Of course a tree would miss sunlight. There seems to have been a permanent cover of clouds over Whitestone for a long time. She sits next to Keyleth and leans against the tree herself.

“Whitestone needed the sun,” she says, “They needed the light.”

Keyleth sighs. “And now they don’t know what to do with it.”

Pike watches three children run across the street in front of them. They’re giggling and chasing after each other, but it seems a little hesitant, as if they’ve forgotten how to be carefree.

She thinks of how young Percy is. How dark and sad, underneath it all. Thinks of Cassandra, posture straight and tongue sharp yet polite, having become the lady of Whitestone long before her time.

“They’ll figure it out. They have time to learn how to be happy now,” Pike states, and when Keyleth looks her in the eyes, she knows they understand each other perfectly in this moment.

“Maybe we’re all a bit like trees,” Keyleth muses, “All we can do is grow towards the light.”

And, because that’s just such a Keyleth thing to say, Pike laughs and squeezes her arm.

“Please don’t ever change.”

Keyleth hums and leans back against the rough bark of the Sun Tree. “If I do, I’ll always have you to set my head straight again.”

That she does.
